## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2022-10-31T17:19:32Z
## Message ID: 20221031-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2022-10-31T08:30Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2022-10-29T17:10Z (see notifications 20221029-AL-001 and 20221029-AL-002) are caused by a coronal hole high speed stream that arrived at L1 at 2022-10-28 (notification 20221028-AL-001), reaching a maximum sustained speed of approximately 600 km/s. The solar wind speed observed at L1 is currently around 580 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2022-10-29T17:10:00-RBE-001.

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significant interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR at L1 at 2022-10-28T13:58Z. 

The shock may possibly be associated with a high speed stream from a small coronal hole centered near N20W50, which is likely the same coronal hole responsible for a high speed stream at STEREO A on 2022-10-26.  Some magnetospheric compression and geomagnetic storm may possibly be expected. 

Activity ID: 2022-10-28T13:58:00-IPS-001.

## Notes: 

This signature is still developing, and analysis is still ongoing.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 19, 2022 - October 25, 2022
##
## Message Issue Date: 2022-10-26T21:18:38Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2022-10-19T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2022-10-25T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20221026-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at minor levels during this reporting period.  There were 8 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs were predicted to impact:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2022-10-19T11:00Z    OSIRIS-REx at 2022-10-22T10:34Z (notification 20221020-AL-003)
2022-10-19T23:24Z    OSIRIS-REx at 2022-10-22T10:34Z (notification 20221020-AL-003)
2022-10-21T02:48Z    OSIRIS-REx at 2022-10-23T22:11Z
2022-10-22T06:12Z    OSIRIS-REx at 2022-10-25T04:14Z

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp = 5 occurred during the synoptic periods 2022-10-22T09:00Z-12:00Z and 2022-10-22T15:00Z to 2022-10-22T21:00Z. This elevated value of Kp may have been associated with the potential arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2022-10-22 with the associated interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2022-10-22T07:30Z (see notification 20221022-AL-001). The maximum sustained solar wind speed observed by DSCOVR at L1 reached approximately 595 km/s. Currently, the solar wind speed is around 350 km/s. STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments detected an interplanetary shock at 2022-10-20T23:22Z that may have also been associated with the previously mentioned coronal hole high speed stream.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt was already elevated but below the threshold of 1000 pfu at the beginning of this reporting period (on 2022-10-19) due to a coronal hole high speed stream in the previous reporting period detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2022-10-14. On 2022-10-20T13:50Z, the energetic electron flux crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu again (see notifications 20221020-AL-001 and 20221020-AL-002). These elevated electron flux levels were likely caused by the lingering effects of the above mentioned coronal hole high speed stream. The energetic electron flux levels decreased to background levels late on 2022-10-21.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been minor to moderate this week due to the effects of the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2022-10-26T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2022-11-01T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at minor to moderate levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently 5 numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13126 (S10W70) was the source of B-class and C-class level flaring during the reporting period. Newly numbered Active Region 13133 (N25E65) has been the source of recent C-class flaring and may continue to exhibit flaring activity throughout the outlook period. An unnumbered Active Region is visible on the STEREO A facing eastern limb around latitude N25 and may be expected to rotate onto the Earth-facing disk on or around 2022-10-28.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels throughout the outlook period. There is a small coronal hole centered around N25W25 that may become geoeffective around 2022-10-27. A coronal hole centered around N05E10 may become geoeffective around 2022-10-30.

ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Summary:

Multiple CMEs have been detected as follows:
1: C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2022-10-19T11:00Z.

Estimated speed: ~623 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 20 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 112/13 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2022-10-19T11:00:00-CME-001

2: C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2022-10-19T23:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~760 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 10 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 104/17 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2022-10-19T23:24:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CMEs may impact OSIRIS-REx.  The leading edge of the CMEs will reach OSIRIS-REx at 2022-10-22T10:34Z (plus minus 7 hours).

## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at minor to moderate levels during this reporting period with 2 M-class flares (see list below).  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact non-Earth locations:

CME Starting time  |  Predicted Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2022-10-17T04:36Z    OSIRIS-REx at 2022-10-20T10:30Z (notification 20221017-AL-001)


Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp = 5 occurred during the synoptic period 2022-10-15T00:00Z-03:00Z. This elevated value of Kp was likely associated with the arrival of the coronal hole high speed stream first detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2022-10-14 but may have been bolstered by weak glancing blows from one or more of the CMEs with IDs 2022-10-09T23:48:00-CME-001, 2022-10-11T09:23:00-CME-001, and 2022-10-11T11:36:00-CME-001 (see notification 20221014-AL-001). This solar wind signature is still undergoing analysis. The maximum sustained solar wind speed observed by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 reached approximately 580 km/s. Currently, the solar wind speed is just under 450 km/s. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was elevated above the threshold level of 1000 pfu early in the reporting period until 2022-10-13 due to an initial threshold crossing in the previous reporting period beginning at 2022-10-05T14:40Z (see notification 20221013-AL-001).

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been minor this week due to the waning effects of the RBE described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2022-10-19T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2022-10-25T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at minor levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently four numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk.  The most notable of these, Active Region 13124 (S34W68), has produced only C-class flaring and should rotate off the Earth-facing disk by 2022-10-21.  An unnumbered Active Region near N20E95 is visible on the STEREO A eastern limb and just over the SDO eastern limb, may be expected to rotate onto the Earth-facing disk by 2022-10-20, and may produce some activity throughout the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels throughout the outlook period. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt is currently elevated but below the threshold level of 1000 pfu, as a result of the coronal hole high speed stream first detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2022-10-14, and may remain elevated through the beginning of the outlook period. There is a large coronal hole centered near S35E35 that may begin crossing the Earth-facing central meridian on 2022-10-20 and may reach geoeffective longitudes by 2022-10-24.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2022-10-05T14:40Z are caused by a coronal hole high speed stream which arrived at L1 on 2022-10-03, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 605 km/s (see notifications 20221005-AL-002, 20221005-AL-003, 20221007-AL-001, 20221009-AL-001, and 20221011-AL-001). ## Summary:

Solar activity varied between minor and moderate levels during this reporting period with 5 M-class flares, 3 O-type CMEs, and 6 C-type CMEs (see details below).

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact non-Earth locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2022-10-08T04:24Z    OSIRIS-REx at 2022-10-11T01:34Z
2022-10-11T08:48Z    OSIRIS-REx (glancing blow) at 2022-10-14T10:00Z (notification 20221011-AL-002)


Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 1000 pfu starting at 2022-10-05T14:40Z and remained elevated through the end of the reporting period (see notifications 20221005-AL-002, 20221005-AL-003, 20221007-AL-001, 20221009-AL-001, and 20221011-AL-001).  These elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2022-10-03, reaching a maximum solar wind speed of approximately 605 km/s. The current solar wind speed observed at L1 is around 400 km/s.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been minor to moderate this week due to the ongoing elevated energetic electron flux levels in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2022-10-12T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2022-10-18T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently five numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk with the most notable Active Regions 13112 (N22W63) and 13116 (N29W62) producing multiple M-class flares throughout the reporting period.  These Active Regions may continue to produce flares as they rotate off the Earth-facing disk by 2022-10-14.  An unnumbered Active Region visible on the STEREO A-facing eastern limb (centered near latitude S30) rotated onto the Earth facing-disk on 2022-10-12 and may produce activity throughout the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels throughout the outlook period. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt currently remains elevated around or above 1000 pfu, as a result of the coronal hole high speed stream mentioned above, and may remain elevated through the beginning of the outlook period. There is a small coronal hole centered around N35W15 that may reach geoeffective longitudes by 2022-10-15.

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 5 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp = 5 occurred during the synoptic periods 2022-10-02T21:00Z to 2022-10-03T00:00Z and 2022-10-03T18:00Z-21:00Z. These elevated values of Kp were likely associated with the arrival of the coronal hole high speed stream first detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2022-10-03 (see notification 20221003-AL-002), possibly combined with the arrival of one or two small transients. The maximum solar wind speed observed by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 reached values of 605 km/s. Currently, the solar wind speed has values around 520 km/s. STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments detected an interplanetary shock on 2022-09-29 that may also have been associated with the above mentioned coronal hole high speed stream. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A remained below their respective thresholds for the entire reporting period. Following its minor elevation in the previous reporting period, the energetic proton fluxes at GOES, SOHO and STEREO A returned to background levels by 2022-09-30. In the last four days of the reporting period the proton fluxes at GOES and SOHO had periodical slight increases to above nominal (but still below threshold) levels due to the high flaring and CME activity on the last four days.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to minor this week due to the somewhat elevated energetic proton fluxes mentioned above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2022-10-05T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2022-10-11T23:59

Solar activity is expected to be at moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently 6 numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. The most magnetically complex of these, Active Region 13112, has produced seven M-class flares and is expected to remain active during the outlook period, as it traverses the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13110, currently on the west limb, has produced one X-class  and seven M-class flares and multiple CMEs and is likely to continue its activity while it is rotating behind the limb. At least two unnumbered Active Regions currently rotating onto the STEREO A-facing disk (at around N30 and S20) may rotate onto the Earth-facing disk in the first half of the outlook period. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels in the outlook period. Following the arrival of the above mentioned coronal hole high speed stream at L1 on 2022-10-03, the solar wind speed remains elevated at around 520 km/s and the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES exceeded the threshold beginning 2022-10-05T14:40Z (see notifications 20221005-AL-002 and 20221005-AL-003). We may expect some additional geomagnetic activity at NASA missions near Earth around 2022-10-06 due to a glancing blow from a S-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2022-10-03T00:36Z, and on 2022-10-07 due to the arrival at L1 of the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2022-10-04T14:24Z. Additionally, two small coronal holes that reached the central meridian on 2022-10-05 (an equatorial coronal hole currently centered around S02W02 and a southern coronal hole centered around S40E20) may become geoeffective by 2022-10-09.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2022-10-06T13:58Z and 2022-10-07T18:43Z (average arrival 2022-10-07T04:52Z) for 89% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 75% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 4-6 range (below minor to moderate).

This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A. 

Start time of the event: 2022-10-01T13:09Z.

Estimated speed: ~671 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 40 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 28/5 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2022-10-01T13:09:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may affect Mars and STEREO B.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Mars at 2022-10-05T20:07Z and STEREO B at 2022-10-04T14:38Z (plus minus 7 hours). 
  
The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2022-10-04T05:43Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 4-6 (below minor to moderate).
